By 1681 Aurangzeb has reached the lowest level of religious bigotry. He issued a farman to destroy Jagannath Temple. He ordered his subedar of Bengal Province ,Amir-ul-Umara to demolish it.

Receving the farman the Officials arrived in Puri to destroy the temple. Odisha was under the mughal rule,however it still had the king of Khurdha known as Gajapati who acted as the protector of the temple. Now listening this news there was fear, anger and desperation everywhere. But everyone was helpless. So finally a plan was carved out. There was a negotiation with the mughal subedar . He was offered a huge amount of money as bribe. Still he knew the consequences of not executing Aurangzeb's order. However, the bribe amount was huge and Odias were successful in persuading him with the offer and he finally decided to take the risk and somehow convinced Aurangzeb that his order has been carried out.

  • A replica of lord Jagannath was created and it was sent to Aurangzeb's court in Delhi to mislead him.
  • The temple was closed permanently. All the rituals were stopped. The pilgrimage was stopped. A rumor was spread that jagannath temple and the idol has been destroyed.
  • Annual puri Rath Yatra was stopped

By doing all this an atmosphere was created in such a way that Aurangzeb believed that his orders has been carried out.

During that time the Marathas down south were creating a huge problem for Aurangzeb. Therefore, he had to come to Deccan to suppress the rebellion. Sikhs, Jats etc were constantly creating trouble. So, Aurangzeb was not able to concentrate on these kind of matters.

So, a big thanks to Marathas and other groups because of whom the pride of Odias and Hindus the Jagannath temple was spared from wrath of iconoclasts. Finally the temple was reopened in 1707 after the death of Aurangzeb and Rathayatra restarted.

⚫ Why didn't Aurangazeb destroy the Shivalinga?

Answer:

Because priests of the temple took the Idol and threw it down in well safely.

Later In 1828 Baiza Bai Scindia, widow of the Maratha ruler Daulat Rao Scindia of Gwalior State, built a low-roofed colonnade with over 40 pillars in the Gyan Vapi precinct.

Here is the story behind reconstruction of present day Kashi Vishwanath Temple.

Maratha warrior Malharao Holkar

In 1669 Emperor Aurangzeb destroyed the temple and built the Gyanvapi Mosque in its place. [The remains of the erstwhile temple can be seen in the foundation, the columns, and the rear part of the mosque]

On June 27, 1742, Malhar Rao Holkar, the Maratha general, with a cavalry force of over 20,000 soldiers reached the vicinity of Kashi. Holkar planned to pull down the Gyanvapi mosque constructed at the site of the Kashi Vishwanath temple by Aurangzeb & to rebuild the temple.

[ Just like Marathas in past pulled down the Mosque from Trimbakeshwar & Mahakaleshwar Jyotirlingas and rebuilt those temples]

But the Hindu pandits of Kashi sent a delegation requesting Holkar not to do so as as they feared that who would save them from Nawab once the Marathas left.

As the incident in Kashi demonstrated, Malhar Rao Holkar had to restrain himself from levelling the Gyanvapi as the Marathas did not exert enough influence in the region.

If they pursued any such actions, Hindus in the region would have suffered.

Maratha Queen Ahilyabai Holkar

In 1780, Malhar Rao’s daughter-in-law, Ahilyabai Holkar constructed the present temple adjacent to the mosque as a temporary measure.

We should stop glorifying invaders.

The last few days of Aurangzeb were pathetic.

He had severe pain in his limbs, but still he continued to labour. As Aurangzeb continued to sink, consternation gripped the imperial camp. Miraculously Aurangzeb recovered.

After a 6month stay at Devapuri, he began his journey towards Delhi. On 31st Jan 1706 he camped at Ahmednagar exactly at the same spot where he had camped 22years ago.

The old emperor had completed a cycle.

From Ahmednagar, he was expected to proceed to Aurangabad and from there to Delhi, but when the imperial officer at Aurangabad requested his permission to repair the citadel to receive him, the forlorn emperor is said to have written, “Ahmednagar is my journey’s end.”

Aurangzeb knew that his death was near and often recited,

In a twinkle, in a moment, in a breath,

The condition of the world changes.

A few days before his death, he wrote his farewell letters to his sons.

The end came on Friday, 3rd March 1707 while he was offering his prayers, he had slipped into unconsciousness and slowly leading to death.

Source :Emperor's of the Peacock throne by Abraham Eraly.

Aurangzeb, good or bad, puritan or liberal, is a part of our history. So is his tomb.

Aurangzeb had made good the expenses to be incurred on his tomb by stitching caps and by making copies of Quran. He was a puritan, an unostentatious individual to the core and, what's chronicled about him in this respect may be factually correct in every respect.

By the way, even Taj Mahal is nothing else but a tomb. And, so is the one & only Gol Gumbaz. So, should anybody rant about ‘demolishing’ it? And also Humayun’s Tomb, Sher Shah Sur's tomb?

The magnificent Gol Gumbaz, seen twice over by me

The tomb is at Khuldabad near Khirkee, the town developed by Malik Amber, the Abyssinian statesman general of Ahmednagar Nizam and, subsequently, occupied and made his base in Deccan during his tenure as governor. Aurangzeb named Khirkee as Aurangabad after him.

After the war of succession, he became the Emperor. Having had’n the subahdar of दख्खन twice over, his ultimate ambition was to annexe the Bijapur and Golconda Sultanates and, more importantly, the predominant force, the Maratha country. Towards that end, he ventured in Deccan after the death of Shivaji the Great in 1680, fully equipped and armed, cavalry, infantry, elephants & camels and artillery.

He conquered and extinguished both Bijapur and Golconda but the Maratha country was a difficult proposition. If he wrested the forts in West, Marathas would reclaim them in East or North. If he attacked Satara, the seat of power of a Maratha faction, Nemaji Shinde attacked Bhopal and Khanderao Dabhade vanquished Bharuch. By 1701, Aurangzeb was frustrated and, was advised by Asad Khan, father of Zulfiquar Khan, to wind up and turn around.

Satara campaign

Worse, Maratha chiefs started hovering around the Mughal camp and plundering from all four sides, a la Santaji Ghorpade, the Maratha cavalry general who raided his camp at Tulapur-Koregaon when Aurangzeb had Chhatrapati Sambhaji executed. Thus, he began giving up and decided to retreat to Ahmednagar.

In 1707, he became ill. He saw his end and foresaw the disintegration of Mughal Empire and, wondered aloud to Azam and Kambakhsh, his sons, he didn't know why he came, what was the purpose of it all.

He passed into elements on 21st Feb, 1707. He was interred initially in his camp in nearby Bhingar and, subsequently, to Khuldabad near the tomb of his preceptor as per his wishes.

Thus, his tombs are a great reminder of the struggle put up by the dauntless Marathas and, the eventual wearing down of the greatest emperor this Subcontinent had seen. The extent of the struggle can be gauged by the fact that as many as a lakh Mughals and thousands of Marathas perished an year at the turn of the century.

I had made it a point to visit the grave, and also that of Malik Amber, in Oct, 2014 during a trip to Aurangabad. Letting alone speaking about ‘demolishing’ the tomb of Aurangzeb, or Malik Amber, or anybody for that matter, about time a proper monument is erected around them to mark our past vis-à-vis those unaware of them and, from the tourism point of view. Let the poor keepers of the graves get their due, a little more than what they can make now.

Why did Islamic invaders demolish Hindu temples?

This question was asked by Raja of Delhi, Anundpal in the year 1011 ce to the most famous (or infamous) of Islamic invaders Sultan Mahmud of Gizhnevy on the eve of the destruction of the temple of Tahnesur.

This question was asked by Raja of Delhi, Anundpal in the year 1011 ce to the most famous (or infamous) of Islamic invaders Sultan Mahmud of Gizhnevy on the eve of the destruction of the temple of Tahnesur.


'The Raja's brother, with two thousand horses was also sent to meet the army, and to deliver the following message:- "My brother [Anundpal] is the subject and tributary of the King, but he begs permission to acquaint his Majesty, that Tahnesur is the principal place of worship of the inhabitants of the country: that if it is required by the religion of Mahmood to subvert the religion of others, he has already acquitted himself of that duty, in the destruction of the temple of Nagrakote. But if he should be pleased to alter his resolution regarding Tahnesur, Anundpal promises that the amount of the revenues of that country shall be annually paid to Mahmood; that a sum shall also be paid to reimburse him for the expense of his expedition, besides which, on his own part, he will present him with fifty elephants, and jewels to a considerable amount." Mahmood replied, "The religion of the faithful inculcates the following tenet: 'That in proportion as the tenets of the Prophet are diffused, and his followers exert themselves in the subversion of idolatry, so shall be their reward in heaven;' that, therefore, it behoved him, with the assistance of God, to root out the worship of idols from the face of all India. How then should he spare Tahnesur?'

History of the Rise of the Mahomedan Power in India by John Briggs
Translated from the Original Persian of Mahomed Kasim Ferishta

Raw letter of decrees issued by Aurangzeb to break Hindu temples

1. October 13, 1666- Aurangzeb ordered the breaking of the carved nets from the Keshav Rai temple in Mathura, which were offered by his elder brother Dara Shikoh, saying that any Muslim should even look at a temple. Is forbidden And what Dara Shiko did is illegitimate to a Muslim.

2. 12 September 1667 - The famous Kalkaji temple in Delhi was demolished on the orders of Aurangzeb.

3. After the death of Mirza Raja Jai ​​Singh Amber on 9 April 1669, Aurangzeb was ordered to break all the Hindu temples in his entire kingdom and ban any kind of Hindu worship. After which the temple of Keshav Dev Rai was dismantled and a mosque was built in its place. The idols of the temple were broken and taken to Agra and buried in the mosque stairs and the name of Mathura was changed to Islamabad. After this, Aurangzeb also destroyed the Somnath temple in Gujarat.

4. On 5 December 1671, with the order to implement the Sharia of Aurangzeb, the idol of Shri Nathji at Govardhan was taken by the Pandits to the village of Sihad in Mewar, Rajasthan. Where Rana ji assured him that one lakh brave Rajput warriors would have to die before reaching this idol of Aurangzeb.

5. On 25 May 1679, about the idols looted from Jodhpur, Aurangzeb ordered that the gold-silver-diamonds should be furnished in the Jilalkhana and the remaining idols should be buried in the stairs of the Jama Masjid.

6. On 23 December 1679, by the order of Aurangzeb, the temples built on the banks of Lake Maharana of Udaipur were demolished. Jagannath's temple built in front of Maharana's palace was saved by a handful of brave Rajput soldiers by his bravery.

7. On 22 February 1980 Aurangzeb attacked Chittor and broke 63 temples built by Maharana Kumbha.

8. On 1 June 1681 Aurangzeb ordered the demolition of the famous Puri Jagannath temple.

9. On October 13, 1681, Aurangzeb ordered to build a mosque to the temple at Burhanpur.

10. On 13 September 1682, Aurangzeb ordered the demolition of the Nand Madhava temple in Mathura. Thus many decrees were issued by Aurangzeb to dismantle Hindu temples.

In this case, a 24/7 live chat support would be the best option since you would receive help any time in a day, clearly describe problems you could be facing and also receive easy to follow instructions.
  • .in Domains. If you prioritize .in domain then keep in mind that not all hosting providers sell those. You could also buy a domain from somewhere else - just make sure that you know how to point it to your host.

Bonus things to look into:

  • PHP 7.4. You should always look for the most recent version of PHP. At this time it’s PHP 7.4 released on November 28, 2019. Exciting new features like preloading and improved performance and speed are only a few advantages compared to the older versions. I highly recommend reading more about why it’s recommended to use the latest version of PHP.
  • Data servers. It’s always best when your hosting provider has data servers in the same region as you are, so the latency would be minimal. In this case, if you’re in India - choosing a hosting provider with data servers in the Asia region would be a smart decision.
  • WordPress optimization. 34% of the internet is powered by WordPress. It’s quite likely that you will decide to create a website using it. So, choosing a hosting provider that is optimized for WordPress would be a flawless move. Some web hosts also offer a really easy WordPress installation and onboarding, so you won’t need to worry about that.
  • Free website builder. If you’re not fond of CMS and don’t want to learn to code a website yourself; there are alternative ways to create it. Some hosting providers have built-in website builders that are simple to use and have many possibilities as for website functionality and design.

As you can see there are some things to consider and research, but in the end, everything depends on what kind of website you are going to host.

I wish you the best of luck with your work!

What is the story about Naga Sadhus defeating Aurangzeb's forces in Varanasi?

Auranzeb and his army marched towards Kashi Vishwanth Temple to destroy it.

The Naga Shadus who were most of them belonged to Dashanami Sanyasis, organised by Adi Shankracharya, the oldest, biggest, the most effective monastic order, defended the temple and deafeated Mughal Army. And this battle was known as Battle of Gyan Vapi.

Our school history textbooks won’t mention this nor do any historian openly say, but indeed they will leave no opportunity to glorify barbaric Mughals.

We do get mention of this battle in James Lochtefeld The Illustrated Encyclopedia Of Hinduism vol 1 twice:

First mention:

Battle reportedly fought in Benares by the Naga ascetic warriors of the Mahanirvani Akhara. According to a handwritten book in the akhara’s archives, in 1664 the akhara’s soldiers won a great victory near the Gyan Vapi well. This document simply states that the Sanyasis were victorious against the forces of “the Sultan,” although historians have inferred that this figure was the Moghul emperor Aurangzeb. If the story is true, this battle may have been a con- tributing factor in Aurangzeb’s decision to raze the Vishvanath temple in 1669. In light of this claim, it is possible that the temple’s destruction was motivated not simply by intolerant iconoclasm, but by the desire to inflict punishment for resistance and rebellion.

Second mention:

The name of a group of the Naga class of the Dashanami Sanyasis, a type of renunciant ascetic. The Dashanami Nagas are devotees (bhakta) of the god Shiva, organized into different akharas or regiments on the model of an army. Until the beginning of the nineteenth century, the Nagas’ primary occupation was as mercenary soldiers or traders; both of these have largely disappeared in contemporary times. This akhara is described as taking part in a battle with the forces of the Moghul emperor Aurangzeb in 1664, and are credited with saving the city of Benares from being sacked.

Even Jadunath Sarkar has mentioned same thing in his book A History of Dashanami Sanyasis under name of Battle of Jnan Bapi:

Jadunath Sarkar described this as great glory to Naga Sadhus.

Was Aurangzeb responsible for the downfall of the Mughal empire?

What Akbar had built up, Aurangzeb undermined and the ultimate ruin was a matter of time.

Unusually brave clement, just and benevolent Aurangzeb’s all actions were tainted by suspicion and religious into­lerance. In the political sphere his lifelong endeavour to govern India strongly ended in anarchy and disruption.

Aurangzeb’s long absence from the capital had given rein to disorder in the north, the Jats had risen near about Agra, the Raj­puts were in open rebellion, the Sikhs challenged the Mughal autho­rity in Multan, the Marathas in the Deccan were pillaging towns, ravaging fields and villages.

The Bundelas and the Satnamis were no exceptions. For all this, Aurangzeb had to thank himself. He had virtues as well vices but nothing influenced his career more than religious bigotry and intolerance. He failed to realize that no power that had not acquired the confidence of, the Hindus could expect to last in India. Naturally, what Akbar had gained and what Jahangir or Shah Jahan despite personal vices and failings had re­tained, he lost, namely, the affection of the Hindus.

It is customary to regard Aurangzeb’s overthrowing of the Mos­lem states of Bijapur and Golkonda mainly because he wanted a triumph over the Sunnis as a cardinal error, for he had thereby re­moved a strong barrier against the rise of the Marathas.

Aurangzeb had premonitions of blood-shed among his survi­ving sons and his dying instruction to his sons was to divide the em­pire peacefully among them-selves. But no sooner Aurangzeb had closed his eyes than a civil war started between Mohammad Muazzem, Muhammad Azam and Kam Baksh, the three surviving sons of Aurangzeb.

What was the condition of Hindus during Aurangzeb’s rule?

Who was he ?

Aurangzeb was a Sunni Muslim fanatic ruler, his aim at that time, is generally accepted to be, to convert dar-ul-harb to dar-ul-Islam (ie. land of Kafir to land of Muslman).

And as such he was [obviously] against Hindu religion, and any non-Muslim religion. He was also against shia Islam, and thought they were non-Muslim.

What did he do ?

  1. He ordered the demolition of many Hindu temples, ordered the destruction of idols in the temples. One being the Chintamani temple in Ahmadabad now replaced by a mosque (let’s make sure this doesn’t get to Shiv Sena…..)
  2. He enforced Jaziya tax on Hindus, which is an Islamic concept (once a caliphate has been established) of tax on non-Muslims, this acted as incentive for them to convert to Islam, one of the many ways Hindus were forced into Islam through means of force and pressure.
  3. Another purpose of Jaziya is to show the inferiority of the kafir, to the Muslman of the land.
  4. British general Douglas Haig, described Aurangzeb as “Aurangzeb was a bigot to whom the religion of the great majority of his subjects was anathema, mischief, idolatry, which it was his duty before heaven to persecute and if possible to stamp out. His methods were iconoclasm, sacrilege, economic repression, bribery, forced conversion and restriction of worship.”

His rather bigoted policies and actions resulted in the down fall of the Mughal empire. And as such one could conclude the condition of Hindus was terrible, Hindu traders were made to pay more tax, while tax from Muslims was often exempted.

It is a matter of great pride, we Hindus still rule this country, we however need to be more united.

Niccolao Manucci (19 April 1638–1717) was an Venetian writer, doctor and traveller, who wrote a first hand account of the Mughal empire.

He writes about “The burial of Music” in his book the Storia do Mogor Volume 2 (page 8) :

[1]

When the musicians held a funeral procession for Music, as a unique way of protest,

Aurangzeb said, - “they should pray for the soul of music and see that she was thoroughly well buried”

Niccolao says Inspite this Nobles didn’t cease to listen to songs in secrecy.
